item.description:
Can there be any argument that understanding the mind can only be achieved by the methods of both science and art? Well, I’m being facetious because as we all know philosophers can argue about anything. But it seems to me that it takes both science and art to grasp the workings of the mind.

Clearly, neuroscience and related disciplines continue to make remarkable progress in the understanding of the brain and, regardless of any metaphysical ideas that you may have concerning minds or a transcendent Mind the science of the brain has to be accorded center stage when claims are made about the nature of mind. But consider the artistry of what we call the mind. Innovative ideas and the notion of consciousness, not to mention the mind-boggling work that is the essence of art displays a kind of knowing that, in my view, science in and of itself is unable to put its finger on. An artist or a creative thinker works in a realm that—while it may be ultimately explainable by science, may also not be truly understandable by science because the artist or the creative genius may work with principles and creative insights that are beyond its expressive potential. In a sense, a great artist is a great scientist of the mind (I don’t think that I exaggerate, but I’m sure many others will feel that I do).

I’m not too much acquainted with the work of Henri Bergson but, from what I know, I think that my thinking about the mind may find accordance with his thought (so I plan to read some of his work).

Basically, my point is that the creativity of an Albert Einstein or a Leonardo da Vinci points towards a knowledge of the mind that transcends the lab. So, in this discussion we will discuss the science and the artistry of mind and examples of differences between them.
